text: Hi, everyone.

Thank you for coming to the
last class of MS&E447 Blockchain

Entrepreneurship
and Technologies. And this is our last
class for the quarter. And today, we are honored
to have an exceptional panel

with Dan Boneh, Daniel Marin,
Jens Groth, and Ravi Mhatre.

So the floor is theirs. I will pass the mic to
Dan Boneh for an intro.
Awesome. Thank you. OK, so-- [APPLAUSE]

All right. So first of all, I
should say it's-- I should feel blessed. It's really quite amazing
to see so many students

on the last week of the
quarter, where everybody's busy with their last project. So thank you all for coming.

I hope it will be a really
instructive and productive hour for you. So we have a fantastic panel.

Maybe I'll let the
panelists say who they are. And as you say who you are, I'll
ask my first generic question,

which is maybe, in
a few sentences, you can say how you got into the
blockchain space to begin with.

So Ravi, why don't
we start with you? Yeah, nice to see all of you. Ravi Mhatre.

A long, long time
ago, I actually was a student at Stanford. I was an electrical
engineering major, but that was only because
CS wasn't in the engineering

department yet. But I've been a technology--
mostly in core--

an investor of venture
capitalist for 30 years now. And mostly, the firm I
started, Lightspeed--

my focus and a lot of the
firm's focus is in core, we call it enterprise,
but it's anything

where there's a deeper
core technology that underlies the product
that is being built.

And I'm trying to think, how
did I get into blockchain? It's just, in the-- I mean, it was--

I think we made our
first investment in 2013, but it was just one of those
things where it's all of you-- really, a lot of new ideas.

It's really younger
generations of people. Every time, they keep seeing and
being excited about the future

before the technology
is really mature enough to make it into real business. And I think, we
probably talked to kids

here at Stanford-- students
here at Stanford, sorry. And, it was a little
like, what's this thing?

But again, if you look
at Lightspeed as a firm, what we do-- what I've done
a lot of, it was really, once understood, that the core
underlying thing about crypto

and Bitcoin-- it is actually a
giant distributed compute system platform.

And as we started to look
into it architecturally, it was just a realization
that blockchains represented

a fundamental and important
architectural shift that we're going to enable new application
computing problems to be solved

at internet scale in a
way that democratized and made accessible
certain kinds of primitives

on top of, I'll just say,
a planet-scale network that weren't ever accessible before.

And Bitcoin, and what we've
talked about is digital money-- I mean, here we
are, fast-forward--

it's 10 years later. I think some of
those are, really, the tip of the iceberg things. But I mean, we got started
because we thought, hey,

if you really think about
Bitcoin as a digital version of gold or money, that was
enough of a broad killer use

case application that we thought
it could pull the platform in. And our view was the
platform was fundamentally

transformational, and
a lot of other things would happen over time. And here we are 10 years later. I think things are
starting to happen.

It's probably taken a
little longer than maybe we all thought in the beginning,
but that's how I ended up in it.

Perfect. Yeah. Jens, you want to go next? Sure, yeah. So I'm Jens. I'm the chief
scientist at Nexus.

I've been an academic
for many years. I've been in cryptography
for more than two decades.

I invented a lot of
zero-knowledge proofs that are my passion,
where my heart was.

I always had the intuition

to the world

would be really

would be really

schemes that others have developed in this area.

So that's all been
exciting to see. It's also a very unusual
path for an academic.

I just wrote papers and

And it actually got picked up. And typically, as an academy,
you have to put a lot of effort into and go out to
companies and convince them

that they should use your
scheme, it's superior, and so forth. And I've really done
nothing of the sort.

I've just put things
out in the open, and then it's been picked up. So that's interesting.

And yeah, I got into blockchain,
so on a personal level in 2019.

So until then, I've really
looked a little at Bitcoin and so forth, that
that's probably a fad.

And it turned out not to be. [CHUCKLES] So like,
yeah, 2019, that's

when I got the chance to go out. And it was time for me
to explore something new.

So I joined DFINITY, and I
worked there for a while. And then recently,
I joined Nexus.

So that's my path into
the blockchain space. Great, yeah. It's a good story. And Daniel, do you
want to go next?

Yes. Hello, I'm Daniel,
founder and CEO of Nexus.

How I got into the

I actually graduated

of cryptography in

And well, I guess the

I'll just be honest. It was just that simple. It was just really fun. The homework, I remember them

It was challenging, but

With that, I would say
that the company that Jens and I are working on, it's more

But just because it has so many

And yeah, that's pretty much it. I'd like to still

thesis, which is great.

Oh. [LAUGHS] Good story. Yes. So, oh, yeah, I should

So the company started

Many of them go into

So how would you-- could you

think is more exciting?

Which area do you
want to invest more in, machine learning,
blockchains, maybe a third area?

Yeah, well, look, if you-- machine learning and
AI, I mean it's--

Don't say both. Stop. No, I would say it's like-- I mean, I'm trying to
remember the exact year.

This was before the last
crypto downturn, when it was really in the up market. I think going into
AI right now would

be like going into crypto then. Now, maybe the cycles in AI
aren't going to be as big,

but there will be
a boom bust cycle. And we are in the
honeymoon first period

of hype and optimism,
and we'll hit some kind of a trough of disillusionment. So if you really
love it, go into it.

But I mean, let me-- I guess what I-- how would I answer that? Because I was thinking about
maybe not this question.

But why am I here. I mean, we're chasing a lot
of things in AI at Lightspeed.

Why am I here? Let me put it this way, the
blockchains, and particularly

this idea of blockchains now
with verifiable computing, what is that? And I was trying to think
about, what's the analogy?

And when I first got out of
Stanford and got into VC, this was in-- when I first
got into VC in the mid-90s,

the thing that was happening-- I don't know where all of
you were in your life cycles

or maybe being
gestated at the time, but it was basically
the internet as the first time you had a
protocol that would allow,

over time, billions of people. At first, it was
millions and then tens and hundreds of
millions of people.

But today, it is
the same protocol that, for a
communication network, allows billions of people
to be interconnected.
And it was pretty profound. And some of-- it was TCP/IP.

It was a lot of layers
that self-described in the network how communication
should happen at scale,

without you having
to know anything. You literally-- you put a packet
in here, and that packet-- it could have to go
through 15 different stops.

And each stop didn't know
the whole of the network, but it knew enough. It was like self-describing
in the protocol

how to take a packet and
move it the next way. And amazingly, you fan this out. And the same protocol
that, hey, it allows.

It's incredible digital
delivery system. And you can set
guarantees malware for how

reliable the delivery
has to be or unreliable, depending on what kind of
media you're trying to move.

But from the beginning, that
was massively transformational. Literally, before that,
every communication network,

you had to know the address
of the person you were sending to it and the specific route. And you can imagine.

I mean, if every time you're
going to send something digitally, you had
to know everything about how the bits
were basically

going to go across some
scheme to get there, it would be impossible to
have the dream of just making

that scale and be organic. And no matter where
you are in the world, you could pick it up and
just plug into the fabric. So why am I here today as
it relates to blockchain?

Really, there's a
couple of things that have happened recently. And we've invested
before because I

feel like we have sensed that
the platform, distributed ledgers, there's
a lot still that needs to be done to
make them scalable,

reliable, accessible so
that billions of people can be on them. But a couple of fundamental
things have changed.

One is actually
the important work that Dan and Jens and
others have done around

with zero-knowledge proofs. But it's basically the
cryptography to, in some way, not have, again, what
I'd call networks

before the internet, which is
point-to-point ways that, if I really want to know who you
are and cryptographically or

mathematically in the
network, I can guarantee that, all the previous
mathematical systems,

they really only worked in
more of a one-to-one way. And that's great for-- we've seen a lot of
what that could do.

But with the new kind of
mathematics and cryptography, this idea that simultaneously
everything happening--

and if this is in
the network, we can know that it happened
the way it should happen.

That's a massive unlock. And why is that? Because it means-- if you think
about the internet with TCP/IP,

that really created a
scalable both language and set of underlying
communication infra

to let the network be scalable
to billions of people. Now you have--

I guess it's really
data and compute. What needs to happen? If you really--
people talk about, the network is the computer.

You want to make those
things part of the network. What you need to do is, one,
have a set of primitives.

Just like TCP/IP
self-describe the primitives for moving, for communication,
you have some with XML.

And there have been other
things for self-describing data. But with things like
Solidity and EVMs and these--

these things within crypto
are the first time we have-- like TCP, it is a standard
set of primitives for--

it's essentially how compute
should happen in an abstracted way where it doesn't-- if you try to get compute
cycles from Amazon, I mean,

it really has to come wrapped
in basically a virtual machine that you get from Amazon. There's a lot of specific
things to what you're getting.

It is not-- it's not
like electricity, where you plug it into the wall. You have no idea
where it came from, and it is all truly the same.

Things like Solidity, EVMs
and what's happening now are exposing primitives such
that compute and data can truly

be-- you won't know where
it came from in the network. It will all be truly the same. And that's what you
need if you're going

to have true cloud computing. So you need that, and then
you need the mathematics of cryptography that--

it's multi-point-to-point
validation of anything happening in the network happen.

Those two things are actually
quite recent in terms of, I'd say, it's just even
like the innovation

to understand that
they were possible. And if you really roll the
implication forward of those two

things, it is pretty profound. Because I think, again, relative
to everything we see happening,

I don't know if
you want to call it Web2 or the way the internet and
the cloud and web applications

work today, with distributed
ledgers and blockchains,

there's a lot of work to do to
make this industrial grade so it can actually work in the
way it needs to work,

and it doesn't fall over. And you guys weren't
around in the '90s. But in the '90s, it was
the same with the internet. Everybody understood the
potential of what it could do,

and it took 15, 20 years to
mature the infrastructure. I don't think it will
take this long that time. But that's why I think
blockchains and crypto--

if you really-- what they're
going to enable is the network to truly be the
computer, where-- and again, a lot of the
things we see-- you want AI.

Well, guess what? You want to have
an agent that can go off and at some
level that understands the protocol for what it
should do in the network

and how it should be
interacting with other programs in the network, and
the data is there. And all of those
things, you can trust

that they're not corrupted. Really, today, our
blockchains, that is going to be the substrate
upon which these things run.

Sorry. I'm going to interrupt
you for just a second. I'm not going to let-- I'll stop. I'm not going to let you off
the hook that easily, though. Yeah.

So still, I want you
to answer the question. So imagine you are 22 years old. You just graduated
from Stanford.

You have job offers from a
machine learning company. You have job offers from
a blockchain company. How do you choose where to go?

I'm going to say,
well, look, you have to decide what's
important to you. If you want to be where the-- if
you want to chase the momentum,

and that's not a-- I'm not judging. You should go do AI. If you want to really be-- I mean, again, from
what I believe,

30 years of technology
investing, having seen what happened with the internet
as a massive platform shift

and then having seen
what happened with cloud computing and mobile smartphones
as major platform shifts have

had huge implications
on our lives. If you want to be
involved with a core-- I guess I'd say, reference
architecture technology that

has the potential to be a
fundamental platform shift, and you want to be at the
stage where it's really

about building and being there
before it's in the hype cycle, I definitely think
blockchains and everything--

I mean, crypto is
the wrong word. It is the cryptography. It is the fact that we
now have technologies

that are exposing in a
standardized way, computing and data primitives
in the network. I mean, that is going to--
it's going to be a hype cycle.

I can't tell you exactly when,
but people are going to wake up. And some number
of years, as soon as this technology is
really at a maturity point

where it doesn't
break when you try to put a billion people on
it, when and-- and also, the other thing
happening right now,

and it's being driven by it,
but it's the cost of GPU compute cycles is coming
down so drastically.

This was never possible before
because even if the math worked, it was too computationally
expensive to do it.

So anyway, there are a lot
of confluencing factors such that if you want to do
something that really is the platform of the
future, I definitely

think, again, blockchains,
cryptography, distributed ledgers-- these are going to drive the
applications of the future.

And I don't know. I mean, it just
depends what you want. For me, as a VC,
that's always exciting.
It's where the puck is going. It's not where the puck is. And I mean, again, I don't-- I'm not judging.

I think you can get a really

you want to have a job in AI.

I just think you--
the chance of working on interesting problems
that really are going

to have the profoundness of
affecting probably-- it's just the future of how we

and machines. And frankly, the

the future, where you have AI,

and it's acting on your
behalf with other things out in the world-- the substrate for all
of that is definitely

going to be some form of
these ledgers that embody many to many cryptography.

They embody the idea that,
hey, things are happening on your behalf, but you
don't-- you take for granted.

Just like, a dollar is a
dollar, no matter where you use in the world,
you have full trust

that whatever happened
in the network is what needed to happen. All of those things
are going to be based on blockchain technology, so--

OK. I mean-- Perfect. So I think you're saying really
that maybe the opportunity for impact maybe is greater
in the world of blockchain,

Probably, yeah. Maybe part of it might

is now huge and attracts

the bandwagon now. Again, I'm not judging.

I'm not telling you that-- I am not saying that's

But yes, I'm probably more
likely describing a person who-- Both options are valid options.

It's just a question
of, how do you decide? So this is great. So Jens, let's move to you.

Thank you, Ravi. This is a great. Great answer. So let's move to you,
Jens, So let's see.

So you've been working
on zero-knowledge now for quite a long time,
two decades, as you say. You've done amazing work in
the zero-knowledge space.

I hope you guys know
that Jens is actually the father of many of the
techniques in zero-knowledge that are used in the
blockchain space today.

In some sense, it's interesting. The reason zero-knowledge, or
I should say succinct proofs,

are useful in the
blockchain space is because a blockchain
is a slow computer.

It's a slow and
expensive computer. So rather than have the
computer, the slow and expensive computer compute
something, it's better

to compute it elsewhere
and then prove to this slow and
expensive computer that the computation
was done correctly.

So this idea is like
a 40-year-old idea. But in some sense,
it took us 40 years until we invented a slow
and expensive computer.

Yeah? And once we invented a slow
and expensive computer, all of a sudden, zero-knowledge
became super-duper useful.

Yeah, it's really-- Yeah. That's at the heart of it. We have very fast
computers, and we have a very slow and
expensive computer.

And a slow and
expensive computer has to verify that what the fast
computers are doing is correct. So what I wanted
to ask you is, this

is the reason why there's
such a good marriage between zero-knowledge
and blockchains. And I wanted to have--

to hear what you
have to say about, where do you see
this field going? Like, what's the future
of zero-knowledge proofs?

Is it going to continue
to improve in speed? Where do you see--
given everything

you've done, where do
you see this going? OK. So there are a couple of
things to unpack here.

And I guess one thing perhaps to
add to what you said, I agree.

It's like, I never
thought about it's really a slow computer that is
[CHUCKLES] making all this very

valuable. But I think there's
also something different about
zero-knowledge proofs,

and particular verifiability. So the cool thing about
zero-knowledge proofs

is that they can be
publicly verifiable. And it could be a short piece,
just a short proof, regardless

of how big and complex a thing
it is that you're proving. And the cool thing
about that is, OK,
so it's expensive to compute. It costs a lot to prove it. We're paying big time for it.

But once you have it, you can
just send it to somebody else. And they don't have to
pay anything for it.

And that's why it's useful
in the blockchain space. But it also enables
some really cool things.

You can have a web
of verifiability. You can spread it out. You can say, here's
a proof of something.

And somebody else
can say, here's another proof of something else. And you can combine those, and
you can do a proof of a proof.

So you can have
this verifiability that spreads out and grows.

And I think that is a big thing. So you're paying a lot
for the individual proof, but you're actually getting
the first bit of something

that can grow into
something much bigger. And so like, what I'm really
getting excited about,

if I think of this like on a
societal impact kind of level, is like, you can actually
have the verified society.

I would love to have everything
you see on the internet comes with a proof. Like, this is the
origin of this data,

and this is how you
know it's correct. And I think even
with a slow prover,

that's something that you may
actually get up and running. And this is a chance to
see that process starting.

So that's, I think,
the big picture. So then the other question is,
OK, so it's expensive to prove.

So it's expensive to
create these proofs. So what is the cost going
to look into the future?

And it's interesting to
compare with Moore's law, which says you put 50%
more transistors

on each chip per year. That's what you were expecting. Right now, I think in
zero-knowledge proof,

we are running at
1,000% per year. It's like, we're
getting 10x, 10x, 10x,

so it's really going to go down. Oh, wait. This is important. You're saying provers
are speeding up

by a factor of 10 every year. Yeah. So you just draw the two lines. And pretty soon, they're
going to be faster
than regular processors. Exactly, right? [LAUGHTER]

So. That's a joke. That's not going to happen. That can't happen. There's a proof
that can't happen.

That cannot happen. And you can-- so
it's interesting. I mean, so right
now, the provers

are getting much faster,
more rapid speed. And I think it's because
computation is just more mature.

So we're getting to all
sorts of bottlenecks that we're fighting with,
and we're not at that stage yet with provers.

So we're seeing 10x, 10x, 10x
over the next years, I think. And then at some point,
it's going to slow down.

And the question then
becomes, what is the overhead? So if you say, what is
native computation, and then

what is the cost of
proved computation, and what is the ratio
between those two,

and what is that going to be? And right now it's like a
million or something like that.

And what is going
to be in the future? And I don't see any lower bound. It's not like, there's
no reason to say that it

couldn't be super close. And in general, when you don't
have an obvious reason why

something cannot work, then when
you put a lot of creative people on it, then eventually
you will hit on gold,

and find ways around it. So if I had to
make a prediction, I think we can get
down to one or two

orders of magnitude in
difference between those. 10 to 100 times provers.

Oh, well, that will
change the world. Yeah. For sure. I actually think we should
put a little bit of more

stress on that point, I guess,
to make sure that everybody here understands. So we're talking
about the comparison between verifiable computation
and just normal computation.

How much more expensive
is verifiable computation from traditional computation?

Because verifiable
computation is a different type of
computation in and of itself. And the problem that we
are trying to solve here

is that it's about a million
times to a billion times more expensive. And we actually use
the specific name

We just call it alpha. And mathematically speaking,
the whole goal of our company

is to get alpha from 1 million
to something like 10 or 30.

This is an abstract coefficient. And most importantly,
I think what's

interesting is that we
think it can be achieved within the next few months. And there is apparently
no theoretical

lower bound to its
value, except one. Actually, I want to make sure--

did you guys talk about the
application of proof systems to blockchains? Or maybe it's worthwhile--

I think I could just do
this in a few sentences. Probably. So imagine you have 10,000
transactions that you want

to verify. Today, the way that's done is
these 10,000 transactions are posted on the chain. And then literally, every single
verifier on chain has to go

and verify these 10,000
transactions on their own. Yeah? So if you think about it,
that's a very inefficient way

of verifying a statement,
where everybody has to verify the statement over and over
and over again on their own,

namely the statement being,
these 10,000 transactions are valid. Yeah. It's much nicer if one
person can verify that 10,000

transactions and provide
a proof, a short proof, like 100 bytes or a kilobyte,
that proves that those 10,000

transactions are valid. And then everybody just verifies
the proof rather than verifying

the 10,000 transactions. So now these verifiers that are
running-- that are basically running the
blockchain, they just

verify a succinct proof,
which is very fast and easy to do instead of verifying
transactions on their own.

So that's the whole
idea why these proof systems are so useful in
the area of the blockchain.

And as Jens and
Daniel were saying, the problem today is that
generating the proof for 10,000

transactions is an
expensive operation. You need to have a lot of GPUs. It's a million times more
work to generate the proof

than it is to verify. But that's OK because we have
GPUs that can do it fast,

and that speeds up and
reduces the cost of the chain. Right. Maybe to do this more dynamic,
maybe we can ask everybody here.

Who here is familiar with
the concept of rollups? Raise your hand. Oh, OK, well, everybody.

OK, well, exactly
what we just described is a concept of a zk-rollup. You can think abstractly
of a zk-rollup

as a method to
parallelize a blockchain. You prove executions--
executions

on a stateful machine. And the problem is just that
it's so expensive to do, and we want to
bring that cost down

to give blockchain applications
much more performance and capabilities altogether.

Yeah, and actually,
that's what that brings me to the question I was
going to ask you, Daniel. So again, we have these large
statements that we'd like

to prove 10,000
transactions are valid. It's a lot of compute power
for one entity to do it.

So in fact, just like
today in the world, there are very few companies who
can train a billion parameter

model. They have to go-- so if a small company wants
to train a large model, they have to go and contract
with somebody else to do it.

In the same way
here, if you're going to generate a proof for a
large number of transactions or for a complicated
statement, you're

going to have to contract
with somebody else to generate the proof for you
because they have the GPUs. They have the compute
power and so on.

And so this has a name now. This is called a prover
network, where you actually go out into the
world and say, I have

a statement, a complicated
statement that I want to prove. Hey, Mr. prover
network, can you please generate this proof for me?

And you would pay
them for the service. So I was wondering if you could
talk a little bit about prover networks.

Where do they come from, and
how are they going to be used? Certainly. In fact, maybe I'll take
a risk, and maybe we

can go even one step beyond. Maybe we can all use
the demo that we usually
ask people to do. Great. OK, so if you guys-- OK, so let me explain first.

So the concept that
we just described is, can we outsource
the generation of proofs

to other people? And there exists a lot of
idle computes in the world.

And so one of the goals of
the Nexus project is to see, can we gather a lot of compute
